g.text: Frontend makes request to /initialize
Mark the projectId from the request as
starting up in the database to ensure
idempotency for further requests.
Create EC2 Instance using AWS API
Wait for instance to be ready using
recursive calls every 5 seconds, max: 10
times.
If the instance isn't ready till then, throw
error.
Once the EC2 instance is ready, wait for
instancce to pass health checks using
recursive API calls to AWS for status
every 10 seconds, max: 10 times.
If it doesn't come up till then, throw
error.
Once the EC2 instance has passed health
checks, create temporary project files
locally, SSH into the instance using
node-ssH and copy the files.
Expose Environment variables configured by
the user for the project.
Clone the app-runner folder from GitHub,
install dependencies and spawn the
app-runner script.
Backend
App Runner Script
Use child_process' spawn command
to spawn the app process.
Mount a listener for stdour and
stderr for the app processes. In
the callback, use the output to
send pings to backend socket to be
forwarded to the client.
Connect to backend using
socket.io-client
Use the wait-on package to check
status of TCP on port 3000 where
the app will run. If it doesn't start
in a set time, throw an error.
Create a tunnel URL to be used
by the client to access the app's
site over HTTPS.
Send it to the backend to forward
to the frontend.
At any point if there is an error or a crash
the frontend is notified of a CRASHED state and is told to break the connection from the socket.
With the socket connections in the room having gone to 0, the EC2 instance is shut down.
If all the above is successful, tell
the backend that the instance is in
the READY state to forward it to
the client and enable the iframe.
